page.title: 07DOBBS WEIR LOCK
page.content: Dobbs Weir Lock is on the new river Lea. This river runs from Luton to the River Thames. The lock was built in 1929. It is 45 metres long and has two gates at each end. These are not the original gates. The top ones got changed in 1978 and the bottom ones in 1980. Eight small boats can fit into the lock. These are mostly pleasure boats. The boat owners like to open the gates themselves. Accidents rarely happen though people sometimes tie the rope too tightly when securing the boats. The lock is mostly used in summer because this is when most people sail their boats. Fishermen are not allowed to fish within 100 metres of the lock because it is dangerous. The lock is looked after by a lock keeper called Mr. Byatt. He lives with his family in a house which is by the lock.
